reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since the Post-Napoleonic Era, Steam users have been tirelessly searching for new ways to beat up friends and strangers. Brawlhalla is one of the latest and greatest in the development of tools to achieve these noble ends.

The game delivers a 2D Super Smash Brothers-esque experience to the PC, enabling you to beat up people by means not necessarily limited to beating up your keyboard and suicide bombing that would make Osama Bin Laden proud.

Brawlhalla offers a rich array of characters. You can pick from the following eight-fingered legends:

-A sentient suit of armor powered by Iranian weapons-grade Plutonium,
-Cowman the Unbroken,
-Super Mohawk Obama,
-A Norse man with a small sword and big bear balls,
-Cuauht√©moc‚Äôs snake charming love child born from his affair with Queen Isabella,
-Diesel-powered Mad Max,
-The infamous Burgundian Baguette Burglar of Bordeaux,
-Asgard‚Äôs mini golfing and pole vaulting champion extraordinaire,
-A spooky scary skeleton,
-A demonic mosh pit ninja,
-The guy who formed the United Kingdom by subjugating Scotland and Ireland with nothing but his beard,
-The girl who made Britannia rule the waves and the sky with lots of steam,
-A cyclops alien Crip from Planet Ferguson (contrary to developer propaganda, Roldakk-9 was actually the city of Ferguson, Missouri),
-A wolf-riding elven Greenpeace activist,
-The gun-toting, law-enforcing cowgirl who inspired Chuck Norris to become a Texas Ranger,
-G.N.A.S.H. Genocidal Neolithic Abominable Smashing Homosapien,
-A heroine from a hi-tech cyberpunk future who is surprisingly adept with a primitive spear,
-A homeless guy from down the alleyway who acquired a sword and a pirate hat,
-A savage anthropomorphic tiger who drove the British out of India. Gandhi promptly took all the credit.
-A teleporting samurai who materializes wooden planks out of thin air,
And the lastest addition,
The vampire-hunting daughter of Scarlet and Lucien who whips people with bungee cords.

In your quest to savagely beat up your friends as well as strangers, you will have a variety of signature moves and weapons at your disposal. These include:

-The Helicopter,
-The Upside-Down Helicopter,
-The Black Lives Matter Hammer,
-A little Birdy,
-Mini golfing with a Battle Axe,
-Storm Surge from Hurricane Katrina,
-A Tractor Beam,
-Roundhouse Kicks,
-Old-Fashioned Uppercuts,
-Jousting,
-The Dust Bowl,
-Hiawatha Snake Magics,
-Slow-Motion Gunplay,
-Pretending to play a xylophone in midair on someone‚Äôs face with a pair of pistols,
-The Broadside Cannon Barrage,
-The Incredibly Versatile Human Torpedo,
-The Baguette Butcher,
-Using a massive hammer as a pooper scooper,
-Spikey Balls,
-and Land Mines.

Overall, after sustained play, your friends will go down in flames and your keyboard will go up in smoke. Therefore, Brawlhalla provides a satisfying experience.

For the price of free, it is outright foolhardy to skip out on this game.

Brawlhalla? this has become more of my life than it is just a game. I can't compliment the good aspects of this ENOUGH.
Lets see why.

-Fun friendly multiplayer action.
-Great for both Casual and Competitive players
-Absolutely F2P, you don't have to pay a dime in this game to have the same equality as everyone else.
-Developers are always on the spot when it comes to issues.
-Every legend is unique and is of equal match, depending on your playstyle.
-Skins in the game add for some character individuality, but they are not required.
-Colors, Exp gain, Legends to unlock as you fight your way through the world of Brawlhalla
-Satisfaction of either winning or learning from matches.
-The weapons are well balanced, (even if most people say otherwise, of course it's difficult to make everything perfect)
-The Game's Open-Beta tag, does not at all mean it plays like a poorly constructed in development" game.
-Friendly Community who has provided both myself and other members a very satisfying experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PLEASE NOTE: This review is no longer being updated, as I do not play Brawlhalla as often as I once did. However, it is still a great game and I reccommend it 100%

Well, let's talk about Brawlhalla for a sec, shall we?

At first glance it would seem as though it's a PC game going for the style of Smash Bros. On the 10th or so glance, it seems as though it's a PC game going for the style of Smash Bros. But with a few twists that keep it mostly seperate.

First of all is the weapon system. I personally LOVE this mechanic. You start off with your weak melee attacks until you pick up a weapon, displayed on-screen as a generic sprite. When that happens, you get a non-generic weapon. Each character has a combination of two weapons that they can recieve. There's guns, spears, hammers, 1 sword, 2 swords, and a rocket lance. That's right, a rocket lance. Though each weapon is not exclusive to their characters, each character has 2 exclusive moves (1 per weapon) that they can use. Each weapon is VERY nicely balanced, and I'll talk more about that later.

There are also items you can pick up, though variety is sparce. There are spiky balls called Mace-Balls, which you throw at enemies. There are land mines, which you can either throw at your opponent(s) or at the walls and floors. Finally, there are plain ol' bombs that will make you stare in disbelief as you fly off into your doom after some ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• throws one at you.

Online play. I'm a little... eh about the quality of the online play at the moment. On one hand, it's incredible to wreck people online and tell them gg" before having all of them ragequit

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although it seems unfair, it's actually amazingly balanced. In almost all ranks there is little to no difference in success with legends, all that matters is skill and practice. And even in the higher ranks where balance makes more of a difference, it's still completely possible to do well with any legend.

Sure the community isn't that great on the lower ranks, and spamming can get really annoying, but after you get past silver theres a huge improvement. Spamming doesn't get you to diamond, and if you try you will get stopped in your tracks in gold. The community outside of bronze, like on reddit or twitch, is really great and not very toxic. Most people are just nice people that would love helping out new people or just talk about the game. If you're looking to improve, you can just head over to twitch and observe, or ask for help.

Another great thing about this game is that there is no pay-to-win ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t hidden inside. You can unlock every character without spending a cent, and theres a new free legend rotaion every week. Daily quests help people rake in more cash, and if you want you can spend money to get some cool bling to show off like skins or taunts, which have no effect to the gameplay whatsoever.

BMG is a great company and puts a lot of love into the game, and you can really tell. Every week they have a stream where they show off things in development, and another one where they just play with viewers. There are raffles in both where you can win community colors, which is a color palette that is only obtainable through giveaways (again, no effect on the game). They really do listen to the community, and they hang out at the subreddit a lot and read most of the posts there.

As for the gameplay, it's super fast-paced and fun, even if you don't even know what you're doing. There are a couple different game types, and you can have up to 8 players in one game for complete chaos. You can either join with a friend and play 2v2 ranked, or go alone in 1v1. It's a little floaty, but there's nothing really wrong with that. You can jump around all the time or stay on the ground, whatever you want. There are light and heavy attacks for both ground and air, so neither one has a distinct advantage. As I said before, this game is actually extremely balanced, and in pretty much anything below diamond, everything is 99% balanced.

So in short yes I would reccomend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-Disclaimer- This preview was written during Early Access. Brawlhalla is subject to change.

Brawlhalla is a dream come true for some gamers. Fans of Smash Bros have always had to turn to a console to sate their chaotic filled tendencies. Brawlhalla finally brings things to the PC/Mac and makes it readily available to everybody. The combat is fantastic, music well done, each character feels defined. It offers multiple game modes, couch co-op, single player and possibly more on the horizon. Brawlhalla seems like indeed something that did come from the heavens and is here to answer all your prayers. However, like most things that are too good to be true, there is something going on underneath the surface. Perhaps a venus flytrap of gaming if you will, showing you its tasty gaming nectar and then eating you whole. What am I talking about? Let's go on a little journey.

The core of the gameplay is exactly what you want it to be. 4 player brawling action is brought to you with a multitude of character choices. Now unlike that other" game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brawlhalla is Smash Bros. with all of the excess mechanics and stage randomness removed.

The goal of the game is the same as Smash: knock your opponent off the edge of the screen. However, it has taken out a lot of the things that made Smash so difficult to learn in recent years and what is left is an elegant game that is easy to understand but hard to master.

Good Movement: The first thing to notice is how accurate and precise the movement is. The movement in other games of this style is often very floaty, making it hard to position your character correctly. In Brawlhalla the movement is 1:1 and easy to predict.

Simple Controls: The controls are mercifully simple: weak attack, heavy attack, jump, throw item, and dodge (and taunt). The key difference between Brawlhalla and other games of this type is the weapon system. When unarmed every character has the same moves, but when you pick up a weapon powerup you will get one of two weapons (randomly). These weapons are set per character, and the light attacks are the same for every character.

There are combos, but they are limited to strings of three attacks at the absolute most. This places more of an emphasis on positioning and correct skill usage - though to be fair, there are a few difficult combos that are essential to very high level play.

Interesting Weapon System: The differences between characters come down to three signature" moves per weapon
hoursPlayed: etc.). While this probably sounds like a negative

column19: and most of them can be used to set up elaborate traps or combos; bounce the bomb against the ground and then kick your opponent into it as it arcs downward.\n\nGreat Training Mode: If you do want to grind out hours in training mode
column20: this game offers you lots of data. You can see the hitboxes of any move
column21: and even slow down and replay each frame of a move to see where the hitboxes and hurtboxes are at any given point. There is the standard combo and damage counter as well.\n\nRecommended to Those With Smash Fatigue: All of this is to say that this is a simplified game in all of the best ways. Sticking to a small set of items and reducing the control barrier makes Brawlhalla a joy to play and improve at. The complexity comes from learning how its design elements interact
column22: more so than grinding out hours in training mode.\n\nThis recommendation is really for people who are not a fan of the increasing complexity of Smash Bros. Fans of that series may be reading this and thinking that all of my positives sound like negatives. If that sounds like you

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brawlhalla is like crack and its hard to get off.

The game is a multiplayer 2d fighting platformer which closely resembles Super Smash Bros, though obviously possessing it's own unique characters and some augmented mechanics. There are quite a few characters and at first glance they all appear relatively the same, until you start using them. The other game I would say Brawlhalla lends inspiration from is Soul Calibur. Routinely, (in SSB style), weapon pickups appear throughout the battlefield.

Each character can use one of two weapons and the weapon you get upon picking up the weapon drop is one of those two. Within that mechanic, each character utilizes each weapon in a slightly different way, resulting in some very stylisticly different fighters. You can also of course duke it out with your fists as well. It's always fun to throw your enemy for a loop by throwing your weapon at them then rushing in and giving them a haymaker to the face.

The game is still in beta and there are very few 'miscellaneous' items on the battlefield, tho it's hard to say what will come as more content is added to the game (just the other day they added another new fighter) but at the moment the combat feels very solid and fair (maps are also quite simple, though there are many variations). I'm going to be giving this game a lot of attention, and several fellows of mine have organized a small tournament for which I am eagerly training up for. This game is awesome.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an amazing, fun game.

As someone who just returned to gaming about a year ago after not playing anything (PC or console) for like a decade, the constant lag and mountains of downloads and the myriad of other issues with online games has been a regular pain in the butt.

I just happened to see this game advertised as a free-to-play on Steam, saw its similarities to Super Smash Bros., saw the great ratings, and gave it a shot.

The incredibly small size of the game, along with its absolute smoothness, is amazing to me.

I've been confused time and again after buying what seems like a very small, non-intensive and non-demanding game, only to find that it drags my computer down to the ground ,barely runs, and introduces itself by necessitating a 2 hour download.

After the 2-3 minute download for Brawlhalla, I seriously imagined that (as with so many other games) I'd find that I'd just downloaded the client, and that I'd then need to create an account for some random company before downloading the 3 gigs of the actual game.

That was not at all the case here.  2-3 minute download, start up the game, and I'm instantly playing.

Just wanted to say thanks to the developers, and I hope everyone else is enjoying it as much as I am.  It's simple, but it's so smooth and fast, and it's great fun.  And the amount of options already - be it 4 v 4 free-for-alls or 1 v 1/2 v 2 ranked games - leaves a good amount to explore.

Great stuff, and I hope other Free-to-play game developers take note.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fresh gold here:

IMO the game is awesome, you can play it all way you want - either 15 minut chillout or serious rumble session. My advice: don't play while you're tired, it really affects your skill and you might get beat to lower rank very quickly.
Some people say there are too few moves. I disagree: with the current number of skills you can execute sick combos and create your play style with each character. As I said, I'm in Gold tier and I cannot do some moves that seem pretty basic, yet still I win a lot. Also, some characters are easier to play, some are harder - but if you learn to play hard ones, you'll rock.

Pros:
+ elastic gameplay, you can choose if you wanna play casually or hardcore
+ large number of characters to play; each character has its style and you must learn how to play them or against them.
+ really nice graphics - I set background from one map as a wallpaper on my corporate laptop ;D
+ Large community, there is always somebody to play

Cons:
- Balance issues - as you're mid Silver, you will hate Hattori. She is simply OP and takes a lot of defeats to learn how to fight against her. Get a few matches playing Hattori to check what are her attacks, strong and weak spots etc. Other characters have their issues too.
- Rude community - at least in my opinion. People can be nice and thankful for a great match, but most of them are kids who get angry while losing and they either DC (one free win, so it isn't that bad ;)) or call you a spammer, noob or worse, no matter if they win or lose. It's a motherf**king game for God's sake, you're supposed to have fun with it. If you don't then why you play it? One dude wished me to die quickly - enjoy your report, mate!
- Too few ranked modes, imho.
- Creating a couch party game is a pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•... I tried to play with my friend on one PC and we didn't manage to establish a game. I know that there is a way, but how to do it? I really wish to screw my friends while they're sitting next to me.

Anyway, if you want a good arcade game to spend some time with and practice your manual skills, the choice is simple. Welcome to Brawlhalla!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is fun with friends and if you only play local with friends then it's a 10/10 for quick fun. However if you're seeking any real competitive element akin to Nintendo's Smash series then you will be sorely disappointed. I'm speaking from the perspective of a Platinum ranked 1v1 Ember player. This game's high end gameplay is filled with button mashing spam, if you are not throwing out a hitbox or a dodge at any given time then you are not playing correctly. Why? This is due to the fact that moves in this game have little to no startup frames or end-of-move lag. Someone spamming sword neutrals in the air and on the ground for example leaves about 5 frames of vulnerability that require you to breach the range of there swords and also touch them with the hitbox of your move lest they just spam out their neutral again and catch you.

The skill element just isn't there, good competitive fighting games are built on the premise of reading your opponents moves and then punishing them. I can call out reads on my opponent all day but this is the only fighting game where reading your opponent doesn't allow you to punish them. A heavy attack of hattori for instance will cover a huge radius with it's hitbox, leave her in the air behind said hitbox and then have nearly no end frame lag. The only way to punish this is move is to literally pre-emptively dodge through the attack, pre-emptive because their is no start-up lag on this huge heavy attack. In this scenario you are forced to dodge frame towards the opponent and simply get hit if he just stands still and does any other move instead.

There must be a counter to this obvious inbalance? Yes there is, it comes in the form of throwing your weapon. Throwing your weapon will hitstun the opponent and allow you to re-equip and attack the opponent within the same frame. Due to the fact that there is no priority, deflection or parry systems in this game it ends up devolving into who can throw their weapon the most. An excellent read followed up by a perfectively timed smash is all made pointless when the enemy throws their weapon at you at the last second with no punishment available for such an audacious and should-be-punishable move. I could go on forever about the games combat flaws but honestly for a free to play game it is good fun but very shallow. I don't recommend taking this game seriously as a competitive fighter as you will disappointed with the shallow button mashing, weapon throwing facade it turns into at high levels of play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Updated as of version 0.2. Updates in (parentheses)*
Brawlhalla is pretty much a smash bro's for the PC, except with a few twists.

Here's a Quick Look video I did so you expierence for yourself what this game is like. I've got a summary below for those of you who just like the short and dirty summary. I won't judge. (Please note that throwing weapons is nowhere near as effective now, resulting in longer brawls and less chaotic deaths)

http://youtu.be/-RJhu-8S4co

The basic concept of this game is to knock your opponents off the stage the most to win a match. There's no health bars to be seen, and only two basic attack buttons, light and heavy. The heavy attack being what you'll need to use if you wanna send your oppenents rocketing off the screen. Now while you can choose to fight with your bare fists, you can also use the few weapons that constantly get scattered throughout the match. Each weapon you pick up gives you a new moveset to fight with exception for some one-time-use ones like the battlehorn, mines, bombs, and spikeball. And that's pretty much all I can say about the mechanics of the game besides you can dodge, too.

However, as simple as it may be, it's still a blast to play over and over again, even better when you have friends over who you can banter with and taunt. It's just satisfying to send enemies bouncing off walls to their demise, even more so when you bounce your weapons/bombs off walls and hit them when they least expected it. I also like when you're waiting a short while for a match to begin, you get matched up with some bots so you're not waiting around and doing nothing.

But let's get some of the negatives out of the way.

Now I know this is early access, so I'm willing to excuse most of these things I'm about to list:
*If you plan to play online, be prepared for terrible lag and characters warping all around the screen. It also isn't fun when you see your weapon connect with an opponent, but it phases through them like a ghost. (Also the online scene is pretty much dead at this point. Not many people playing)
*Although there are 4(5 now) different characters currently, they don't play any differently. While it may be balanced, I'd like some variety. (This has been changed somewhat in the new patch. Characters have different stats and some unique moves depending on what you're using)
*There is currently only 1 stage and 1 mode you can play, which is a straight deathmatch. Now don't get me wrong, the mode and stage are solid, but at least one more map and maybe a team dealthmatch should've been thrown in as well. (There's a new 1v1 match currently, but if you're single player, you have to do a weird thing by turning off bots, which really leaves one left to fight and allows you to play it. You should just be allowed to click a bot to turn it off or have a stage select.)
*The game is super short currently and there isn't much to do/unlock. I've only played for an hour currently and have already seen everything this game has to offer. While this game has great replay value, I'm certain this might turn a few people away for the price this is currently listed at.
*Unfortunately, there is also a lack of unique weapons, too. There's a hammer, sword, lance, and a gun, not including the throwing weapons. While the reskinned weapons they have in there may look like they do something different, they don't, so this limits the amount of diversity and mayhem that can happen on screen.

But hey, even after all that, why do I still recommend this game? Because it's still fun. And if you're willing to overlook just the lack of content it suffers from currently, I'm sure it'll grow into something better. And if the price tag is the issue, this will become free to play in the future, so you can wait until then to get it. It'll probably have more content by then, too.

So to sum it up, this is a solid game that can grow into something much bigger. The local multiplayer is fantastic right now, and if you can stand the lag or maybe get lucky, you may find the online multiplayer fun as well. So if you can look past some the of negatives I listed, you're gonna find yourself having a great time with this game.

(I'll try to keep this review up to date, so when major updates start rolling out, please feel free to yell at me to give another look at this game.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brawlhalla is a 2D brawler made by Blue Mammoth Games and published by Xaviant Games for Windows and Mac.

--Review is updated with new content and changes--

Menu:
First of all i don't know why but the menu is not in 16:9 while the rest of the game is, which seems weird because the game is PC only so far. At the moment i find the settings for both graphics and audio below minimal. Things like resolution settings and audio sliders are missing. Fullscreen or window is there but you need resolution options for it to really help. In a fighting game i really want to change the difficulty of the NPC's as i improve in the game but that option is also missing. The menu is easy to navigate with greyed out buttons for not yet available content.

Controls:
There is full controller support for a fighting game i would love to be able to rebind it but can't. Keyboard and mouse support which is rebindable. Everything feels responsive though fighters feel better with controller. Icons for buttons change ingame depending on what device you use.

Ingame:
Arcade mode is in the form of tournaments against NPC's though with the missing difficulty option it's more of a tutorial mode. The real tutorial mode is also there and you get a 1v1 unlimited battle. The gameplay is satisfying and animations do not disappoint. I feel that the wide and expanding character roster uses mostly similar moves except for the super moves depending on the weapon. Items drop in the battle in the form of spike balls, bombs, explosive diggy bombs? and swords. When grabbing a sword you randomly get one of your characters weapons like dual pistols, spears, katana's or claws. There is a powered lance with which depending on the character you can perform moves like shooting out a steam blast or do a big dash forward. Overall i would like to see more item and weapon variety since the character roster doesn't lack. Characters all look unique and there is a good gender balance.

Multiplayer:
This is where the game shines! Brawlhalla has a very functional matchmaking online multiplayer mode and something that PC games lack so greatly, local co-op. When entering online matchmaking you go into a pre-fight to practise while players are being matched. I was able to get into a match literally 1 second after getting out of the loading screen. It is not possible to see what country a player is from though you do see their names. Lag was very minimal to non existant, however you can't see the latency you or others are having. Steam says there is cross-platform multiplayer but i am not aware of releases other than PC and Mac.

Achievements:
No steam achievements available yet.

DLC:
None known yet.

Conclusion:
Brawlhalla is a satisfying brawler with lots of unique characters and weapons. The game shines in it's very functional multiplayer. I read somewhere that it would be F2P which would be awesome if not let's wait on that price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT: I feel that the original review was too harsh, so I just wanted to clarify that really what it comes down to for me is that I am not a fan of a lot of the game's mechanics, but that doesn't mean it's a bad or poorly-designed game. Take the original review with a grain of salt, I guess:

If you're a fan of Smash Bros and those games appeal to you because of the craziness the games allow, you will probably enjoy this game. If, however, you have any interest in playing games at more than a strictly casual level (maybe you still have friendly competition with your friends but you also have a drive to really get better at a game on an objective level), I wager you'll enjoy Brawlhalla a lot less. A number of other negative reviews have touched on some of the game's issues but I'd like to expand on those and explain why such issues are as potentially negative as they're being said to be.

I've long wanted wanted an alternative to Smash Bros titles, an alternive whose developers have a good understanding of  what makes a game like this fun to play, who understand balance, character diversity, spectatorability, etc., but unfortunately I do not feel that Brawlhalla is that game. Here are the main reasons, mechanically speaking, why I feel this way:

- The game has very floaty movement, and as such, going from air to ground is a very slow process. Each character has three jumps, and each jump gives you several, long seconds of airtime; as others have correctly noted, it feels like you're on the moon. This means that if your opponent gets sent off stage but doesn't die, unless they screw something up horribly, they will make it back to the stage and there's not a whole lot you can do about it. You move slowly in the air so it's hard to position yourself to setup for edge guarding, and on top of that, if you hit an opponent who is offstage, they get one of their jumps back. If you're going to make a game with the objective of knocking your opponent off the stage, why make it so difficult to actually do that?

- On top of being slow in the air, characters are also slow on the ground. Characters appear to have different stats" but even the fastest of the characters run quite slowly. This means that if you try to approach an opponent on the ground
date: because of your lack of speed
recommended: they have plenty of time to react to what you're doing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is: free, simple to play but difficult to master, well balaced and just generally very fun to play. It is very quick and easy to find or create a game . For those interested in more intense play an elo based ranked game mode is provided allowing people to take part in ranked 1v1 or 2v2 games. A large problem with this game is that, being a fast pace brawling game which requires quick reactions and fast movement, you need low latency to be able to do well. If you are someone who has trouble with connection whilst playing online you might not have too much fun playing this game.

Looking at reviews other people have made, most negative comments seem to be aimed at the play style of a lot of players, rather than the game its self. I would agree that playing against these players can be an annoying, however the play style in question that most these people are complaining about can be beaten fairly easily with practice. With lack of this practice I mentioned some people have formed opinions that the game is not very balaced, I am very much in disagreement of this. Any legend can be played at any skill level if the player is good enough, and that is what I would consider good balace.
Oh, and the community is terrible. But then that is no reason to not recommend a free to play game is it.

Anyway, to sum up this review. This game is a lot of fun, free and a very small download. You might find you dont like the game but there is absolutely no reason why you shouldnt try it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If this game caught your eye, it's probably because of a certain Nintendo franchise. No, there's no shame in being one of those people, and yes, it'll probably satisfy that itch.

Brawlhalla is a fighting game, although you probably know that already. The combat is fast-paced, the movesets are varied (for most of the game), and it's easy enough to pick up and play. (A friend of mine was able to beat me after only a few matches.)

The distinguishing characteristic for Brawlhalla as opposed to, say, your favorite Smash game is that everyone starts out with the same, somewhat limited moveset. The focus of the game is weapons - which vary movesets completely and completely change a character's dynamic. Each character has two weapons to keep variety. The weapons feel effectively balaned, although a few characters have somewhat powerful moves. (A good example of that is Cassidy's hammer, down-strong.) The other items are only usable with no weapon, which gives unarmed combat efficient as well.

The other aspects apart from the fights themselves are bare-bones. There's a training mode where you can use any character (as oppposed to the ones in the weekly rotation), a tournament" mode
date: and a shop. The shop carries mostly cosmetic items
recommended: with permanent unlocks for the characters also available (which unlocks use outside of the rotation). Only the fighters and some color schemes (unlocked after playing a certain fighter a lot) are available with the regular currency - the others require Mammoth Coins
hoursPlayed: which translates into real money. A pack of all the characters at once is also avialable - which also contains unrelased fighters.\n\nThe game is still in beta

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brawlhalla reminds me of Super Smash Bros. Back in the day I used to love versing my friend on Super Smash Bros Melee on their GameCube, and because of those memories, I really love this game. First of all, let's go over the positives. That may seem backwards, but it'll lead up to my major gripe with this game.

Positives:
Really responsive gameplay on keyboard: I myself play with the Mouse and Keyboard set up. I feel like I'm always hitting what I should and missing what I should, the developers have done an awesome job with this, even though I live in Australia and we need to play on SE Asian matchmaking.

Cool characters: I myself love playing a plethora of different characters such as Bodvar, Teros, Asuri, Orion and Lucien, and the lore that the devs put into the little world they've created really sucks me in. I love reading their lore when I'm waiting for friends to launch the game (which launches surprisingly fast), or if I'm just not playing at that moment.

Awesome Lore: I know I touched on the lore when it came to the above positive, but I believed I had more to say about it. I simply love the lore, and the little tidbits they have around the character's main lore show how they relate to other characters and also what they did before arriving in Valhalla.

And now, the:

Negatives:

Really, the only negative I can find is the spammability of the characters. Keep in mind, at the time of this review I have only 10 hours, so don't take my opinion like it's law, but that's my major gripe. Whenever I go up against a Hattori in my current 1v1 or even 2v2 ELOs (Both Bronze as of 16/11/2015), she seems to spam her Directional Heavy (Left/Right Rightclick/Rightbumper/K/X) every time I come close, so whenever I'm playing a character like, say, Teros, who's Heavy attacks need to be timed down to the split second, I feel at a disadvantage, and it always seems that way aswell, as whenever I believe I'm close to getting my Player Elo back to Silver, I get dropped down by a button mashing Hattori.

That's the positives and negatives I've found with this game in my 10 hours of gameplay, they've done a very good job for a F2P game.

And the moment you've all been waiting for, the  TL:DR VERSION!

All in all, the game is pretty polished in a lot of the major areas, but there is also that, in my opinion, too-small gap of player skill. There's skilled players in the low to high elos and Not-So-Skilled spammers in the even higher elos. That being my major and only problem. Either way, I can totally recommend this to fans of Super Smash Bros and other Fighting Action Platformers.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEven in EA this game is polished and worth the price tag. It borrows just enough from the Smash Bros series to feel familiar but implements a few larger, new ideas to give the game more depth than its influences. The competitve players should be happy to hear that most of the balances made to the game are based around 1v1 matches with 4 player FFA being a sort of party brawler mode. I can't recommend this game enough, especially if you are the type of person who is looking to get a Smash Bros fix away from a Nintendo console. Be warned though, you might not want to go back.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Super Smash Bros. Brawl Simulator 2015. Well, for PC at least.
This is one AMAZING game, one AMAZING BETA! It can only get better. It is basically Super Smash Bros. Remixed. I know that everyone will now think this is a crappy knock off title, as everyone did with Terraria, but it really isn't. For a start, it is alot more contested, meaning CPU's CAN win games. Getting a KO is different too. Instead of knocking your opponent off the map, you need to SMASH them until they are out of returning range. Therefore getting kills really feels like an achievement everytime you do it. The score system has been kept simple, and understandable. 3 lives, once all 3 of your lives are gone, you are removed. In this case, simple is better. A wide variety of unique and enthusiastic characters for you to explore, each with different advantages and disadvantages to the game. The display is beautiful, you couldn't ask for much more with respect to the boldness and brightness of the colour schemes. It really makes the game vibrant. Your attacks are different for each character. You get a quick attack and a heavy attack, obviously quick attacks are less powerful than heavy attacks but can be pulled off to get an enemy away from you in desperate times. There are alot of gamemodes too, and enough people to play full length matches. But seriously, this game is only in BETA, and has the credentials of a full released title. It's a beta I'm finally proud to be part of, because as it stands, this game has full potential to expand and make it's way to new platforms. I'd seriosuly recommend getting over to the BrawlHalla website and signing up for this.
For a Beta Rating, I give it a 10/10 ALL DAY.
For a full game, I'd give it a 9.5/10. That's only because there is currently 1 beta server. However when it's out of Early Access more will be added. So it could easily get a 10 rating from me.

It's certainly more fast-paced than Smash, and you can have consider more airtime with jumps and dodges.  This brings a new dimension to the game, in my opinion.

The art style is pretty great, and the attacks are very stylistic.  So far I've been enjoying it greatly.. is it weird that I wanna use my Gamecube Controller instead though?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh boy where to start?
Possibly one of the few early access games i've had the pleasure of enjoying, brawlhalla stand alone 2D  brawler that truly stands to make its own in the gaming world, enabling both local and online play with friends and many other brawlers around the world.
Though there has been contreversy over early access games, this provides an experience with tons of replay value,  an active development team, with a community growing at an alarming rate thats already providing a collage of feedback to developers which will help shape the future of this ever-expanding game.

9.5/10

Pros
active AND friendly community
Solid gameplay
Stable netcode
Wonderful visuals
Balancing gameplay
Expanding roster of chracters

Cons
Early access game in closed beta that still has bugs to sort out with every release that may inconvenience other players

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brawlhalla is almost everything I'm looking for in a PC Smash Bros-style game. The graphics are clean, gameplay is smooth and fluid, built from the ground up to be competitive, and overall a joy to play.

The Pros:
It's free to play
Free Legends" Rotations
No Pay2Win options (microtransactions are purely for cosmetics)
Not much grinding required to unlock "Legends" permanently
Skill based fighting mechanics
Very balanced metagame
Decent amount of content with more to come
Passionate developers who are very responsive to community feedback and suggestions
The Cons:
Servers can be laggy and desync at times
date: which can screw people over during ranked matches\nThe community is relatively small (It's growing
recommended: but slowly. This game isn't everyone's cup of tea)\nThe top rankings are dominated by a few pros and their smurf accounts\nI'm definitely looking forward to putting more hours into this game. It's been a blast to play with friends and online. I wholeheartedly recommend this game to brawler/fighting game fans

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
-A very promising and refreshing SSB alternative.
-Great art style and smooth visuals. Some what cartoony but not too childish
-High skill ceiling in terms of various movement+attacking skill moves, as well as stragegies for individual matchups and map control.
-No pay to win aspects w/ unlocking characters/items. (All store items are purely cosmetic)
-The cosmetics items (Hats) are nice! There is a Jet Set Radio costume/set for one character... Nuff said
-Still in Beta stages showing potential for large roster additions plus consistent balancing and shifting of current meta-game and tier-list
-Solid experience thus far w/ latency and net-code. (It should be noted that I live in Atlanta, GA where their dedicated US server is located)

Cons:
Maybe would like to see some sort of Story mode with bosses/challenges etc

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A solid game. With an involved team.
An interesting take on the Brawl genre, which is far away from Smash Bross but still captures the fun of the 4 players couch battle.
Characters used to lack of distinct moves, but updates add them along the way.
Still a very living game.

Casually, it's a very fun game that you can play with friends. With a lot of options, and characters are well designed . There's a wide range of various designs which can please mens and womens alike.

Competitively, It's alive and well.
Did manage some small tournaments, and the more used to versus fighting games players than me thinks the game is kinda good now (floaty at first, but it has been patched since)

The basics are still being watched by the devs so they use to try a lot of stuff in their patches in order to balance it.

The free to play part was added. Buying ALL the (mainly cosmetic) things will be costly. But the main part (character and stuff) looks to be subject to a generous free rotating roster, + a bundle that unlocks past AND FUTURES characters (as if you buy a fighting game) which is kinda cheap.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBrawlhalla is really its own game, not just a clone of Super Smash Bros. While the underlying concept is identical to that of Smash games, Brawlhalla has its own set of unique mechanics that make the game what it is. It has such a fluid combo system, and at high levels, followig up an attack or landing a combo can be very mechanically demanding, giving Brawlhalla an extremely high skill cap. The game is similar to Smash in that both are so unique in ways that can't be verbally explained. For those wishing to pick up another 2D fighter and play it at a competitive level, I'd absolutely recommend trying Brawlhalla.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brawlhalla is a 2D brawler game, emulating the stlye of Super Smash Bros but adds it's own little spin and feel to the genre like, having a weapon system that modifies your characters attacks. Each character being able to wield one of two weapons that randomly drop in the map, but at the cost of not being able to grab anything else like mines, spiked balls and other items. The characters have their own stats and are pretty much the same moveset wise, unless when they have their weapons equipped then the get a unique neutral smash attack.

Now in beta, with added characters and music tracks, the game itself is more enjoyable. Smoother animations, more weapons, diversity in the cast, the weapons and the soundtrack and now a market" ala LoL (League of Legends) with minor things

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPlay one of 14 different characters, each with unique weapons and abilities to use in either Solo-tournament play against NPC Characters, or Online PVP, Custom Online play, or Ranked 1v1 battle. The stage I played in the solo-play tournament, was a king of the hill style 3 on 1 match. Myself and 3 NPC players each used combo moves and various weapons that dropped from the sky to knock each other off the plateau. The characters are cartoonish, but kinda cute and the play-style is simplistic but actually a lot of fun. I normally don't like PVP games, but this one was fun to play. Now it is still in the Beta stage, so it is subject to change, but Brawlhalla would be fun to play with friends as it currently stands.

So laggy that moving side to side will cause your character to fall off the stage
99% of Brawlhalla community spam heavy attacks non-stop
Developers are focusing more on adding more characters than balancing them
Missons don't have any creativity
Maps are extremely flawed

Overall
The game is good, except you have to deal with all of the cons above. The biggest problem for me is the lag, this lag has deranked me from the Gold Ranks down to Bronze. The maps have flaws (picture a single heavy attack knock you off the stage) and the community doesn't help whatsoever.

2/10, game needs balancing.
Don't play until Early Access is finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played this game for like 2-3 hours straight and i can tell you that its very simliar to Super Smash Bros. except that its on the computer and has very diffrent gameplay styles.

While there need some improvments like balancing and animation fixes it feels like a finished product and i will say that i had no trouble what so ever with this game. I recommend that you check out the controls because it doesnt have a introduction but again its not a issue because the controls are pretty basic one button = one command.

When it comes to the connectivity it usually depends on the persons internet capabillity and speed because while i didnt have any lag issues i have noticed that my opponent just stands there and suddenly react. This is something that needs a tweak but im sure they are trying their best to fix it.

The main menu is pretty staright forward. Online, Single-Player, Custom, Couch Party or Local and Finally Ranked 1v1. I have tested all these modes and i had no problems with them at all, The Ranked 1v1 is my favorite mode.

MY LIST OF IMPROVMENTS:
Fix more modes for the Online mode because free for all gets exciting so many times.
Improve the internet connectivity so less lag
Fix the ladder on ranked because i find it hard to climb to another leauge.
Animations. Some animations looks like they his but not really.

MY OVERAL SCORE : 8.5/10
While its a fun game i had some problems with the internet and lag which are just pet peeves of mine but if fixed i be sure to spend another 3-4 hours because i can not deny how fun it is

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun. Lots of fun. REALLY FUN. I went into Brawlhalla loving the art style but doubting I'd get much enjoyment out of it, since I'm terrible at fighting games, and it seems to be most compared to Super Smash Bros., whichI've never really gotten into.  WRONG. The four hours I have played? Those are pretty much all in a row, I can't put this game down.

Gameplay is hectic, action-packed, and exciting- but not so fast that you completely lose track of what's going on in the madness. It's still paced so that you can use some strategy and anticipation to line up some awesome kills.

The game, when launched, will be completely free. The only thing that is in the cash shop is 100% cosmetic items with no impact on your strength in-game. Character skins, taunt animations, etc. The developers are incredibly friendly, intelligent, and receptive. Probably the most communicative devs I've ever had the pleasure of testing for (and I've done a *lot* of betas).

I can't recommend this game enough- buy a founders pack to get in immediately or head to their website to sign up to possibly be selected for a closed beta key. I don't think you'll regret it.

Here's some gameplay of a great come-from-behind-and-win-in-sudden-death victory, ignore the text in the middle of the screen- just so you get an idea of the gameplay. (Any lag in the video is not from the game, it's from the recording)

http://youtu.be/b1cM1yCzQ_w?t=7s

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an Early Access review.

How do I explain this?
It is SSBB[en.wikipedia.org] but with a more complicated approach. You select legends to fight, each with a different pair of weapons (these being Spear, Sword, Gun and Axe) and stances (which determine a legend's Strength/Dexterity/Defence/Speed) and which can be unlocked as you level them up in-game. The game also features a ranked mode (1v1 and 2v2) with an Elo rating and the game is free-to-play with no pay-to-win mechanics. The Gold you gain in battle and by leveling, you can use in buying legends (since legends are free in weekly rotations). While there is a very rare chance of lag occuring (which the developers acknowledge), the game has a lot of fun moments. The game has no chat or microphone system, except in the end of the game for the gg" messages
date: and why would you want something like that?. The developers update the game often and I am happy of how it looks like.\n\nIf you're looking for a fun
recommended: (un)competitive game to play solo or with friends or looking to waste some time
hoursPlayed: without a doubt

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I laugh at the people who have given a negative review to this game when they fail to realize that

(i) the game is in beta and should not meet any standard you have beyond being a brawler
(ii) will be updated and in the process lead to favorable and unfavorable opinion on those updates


To support bullet one, the game is in beta. Don't expect worldwide servers for everyone, although accessibility for many non-American brawlers may be a bit wonky, time will prove to come into your favor.

To support bullet two, the mechanics are also updated regularly, which leads to unfavorable reactions. What do you expect? As stated the game is not complete, it's early access.

Now here's why I recommend this game:

1. Great fun

Each day I've played this game and each day I've enjoyed it. It's a fun brawler you can play for an hour each day and never get tired of because you never know what will happen. I can be fighting one guy and be destroyed to bits by a bomb or fight a newbie and absolute wreck him. It's all unexpected, fustrating sure, but fun! A game that's made me laugh and shout many times!

2. Competitive

As stated it's fun to fight different players in the ranked matches or better yet fight friends in your own lobbies. This game provides a competitive environment similar to Super Smash Bros. I've literally wanted to destroy my computer right infront of me from mind boggling events that's occured to me.

3. First of its kind

There's not many brawlers in the market on PC and that's understandable. The idea of a brawler on a PC sounds silly as a brawler is usually more targetted to consoles with couch gameplay. Brawlhalla decided to take this oppurtunity to create a game not seen much around the internet and thus it's a fresh, new game to play if you haven't gotten into brawlers in the past.

10/10 recommend, will continue to blow my foes away with bombs!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Typically I'm not a fan of clone games, far too often do you get games that are just reskins of more popular existing games. However, while Brawhalla may look like Smash brothers and has some of the same mechanics, it's just different enough to not be a clone in my book;for better or for worse.

Brawlhalla is a 4 player online/local multi-player indie game that is basically smash brothers boiled down to it's most basic components(beta is beta). Do damage to others to get them in the yellow or red, then kock them off the stage for a point. One with the most points at the end wins.

From a graphical and design standpoint, the game is very good looking. The fighters in game gush personality everywhere, they are all very colorful and well animated. There's something for everybody, anything from a one eyed alien to a cyberpunk gunner. If I have one issue with the graphics is that the stages are a little sparse on the activity. Maybe a few birds here and there, a unicorn in the backround, Thor backhanding Loki; soemthing to add a little more flavor to the stages.

Next up is sound; it's pretty good and sets the mood for every battle fairly well. Sound effect could use a little bit more fine tuning as punches and kicks sound like I'm hitting a bag of rice sometimes or full plate wearing characters do not make an audible clang when I slam them into the ground, little things like that.

Next up, controls and options (and netcode, I'll get to that in a moment). The options menu, needs work. A couple of sound sliders and a fullscreen on/off is not a good menu to work with. The game defualts to your desktop resolution, but switching it to windowed soemtiems makes the entire game vanish to a  small window in the bottom corner (Mostly on widescreen setups). Controls are fine for the most part, though I have two minor issues with them; no gamepad rebindable buttons or an attack cancel; the latter of which can cripple a heavy character.

As for the gameplay; I feel there are a few issues that need ironed out. Firstly the game seems to have 3 weight classes; though only 2 seemed to be implemented correctly. An example is in order. All the fast characters in game have low defense and all the high defense characters are really slow moving. Those 2 modles are almostr balanced correctly; the slower oens are harder to knock off the stage and the faster ones are harder to hit (though I say the slower oens need to be harder to knock off by a small bit).

Then you have the middle stat range characters like the viking or armoed knight. Bother seem to fall into soem kinda medium catagory but both function as if they are heavy. On the flip side you have couple other 'mediums' that act more like light characters. It's as if they passes some kind of arbitary stat line that turns them from one class to another. This is kind of a minor issue , but could be irone dout a bit.

I also found a few minor balance issues, mainly the rocket/steam powered giant lance. Not only can you use it as a 4th jump, but the hit arc on the front side is massive and the recovery time after such an attack is a bit too small. It's not too much a bane for the lighter fighters, but is absolutely lethal for the heavier combatants.

I would also liek to see a bit more variation in each character, maybe a bit more personality behind some special atatcks they have at a later date. Although this is a personal preference as mechanically the combat is(mostly) sound and such a thing could ruin that balance.

Lastly I find the jumping to be a little on the predictable side; meaning edge camping could be a potential issues in the future.

However, even with the minor issues the game has (Such as folks having connection issues in places like North Dakota...sucks to be you guy) It's stil a blast to play. With so few good brawling games on pc, let alone one with local AND online multiplayer I can't not recommend this game. Most of what is does is mechanically sound and it's still in beta, meaning it can only get better.

One more thing, the game is friggin free. Yeah, you heard me FREE. You can sign up for beta on the games forum for a steam key and most likely get one. If you like the game, theres cosmetic stuff you can buy or just buy a founders pack for 10$ or so and get a bunch of stuff at discount.

I whole heartedly recommend youze mugs at least try the game. Worst case the only thing you wasted was time.

Video review here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=04EFR1GzJhQ

Early Access Review

Ok, so it's almost been year and I have made it to the top 1,000 players in the world so I know my stuff about this game.
At first you should probably try out all the characters and get used to the one you think just feels right. (Lucien FTW). Once you do that I reccomend going staright into an online FFA just so you can understand the look and feel of your main. I don't reccomend playing ranked until you know all the moves of your main by heart.
Once you do start playing ranked however, get ready to lose because its going to happen.....a lot. Get used to the dodge mechanics, it can be your greatest tool when a Lance spammer coming M1+A or D spamming at you.


One more thing, get involved with the community. Its growing rapidly and you should put your foot down in it and get a title for yourself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This has been a long time coming. Ever since the first iteration of Super Smash Brothers on Nintendo 64, I've been hoping and waiting for a PC version with online support. Now my personal Brawlhalla is finally here and it looks smashing already. Since this game is in early access right now, access is limited but I had no trouble getting in within a few hours of signing up. If you're interested in this game, definitely go and sign up for the closed beta right now.

Gameplay:
It is time to Brawl on PC! Since everyone and their dog has probably already played a version of Smash Brothers, you'll find this game easy to pick up and play right away, Hit an enemy enough times so that your next stronger move sends them flying off the arena, taunt with a nice pose, repeat. The familiar mechanics are all there in a very similar way. Light attacks, smash attacks, a distinct move set for every weapon and an unarmed moveset for when you have none. While in the air you also have access to a triple juimp (because double jump was apparently too mainstream). The dodge move is much more powerful than in this game's ancestor: You can dodge in EVERY direction, even up, down or diagonally. In the air as well. OP much? Not at all, since everyone can use it.

Graphics:
The graphics are okay. Not great, but far from bad. Some animations could use some more fluidity and the artstyle isn't really distinct enough to be memorable, you'll probably thoroughly enjoy what there is already. The health bar isn't really informative yet, unlike the % number in Smash Brothers you'll only get a colored indicator that lets you know about how far you'll knock back the enemy.

Sound:
While the sound design is nothing to write home about - it really isn't memorable and lacks impact - the music is FANTASTIC. You'll get the soundtrack stuck in your head even after the first match and find yourself humming along as early as the second. Here's hoping the sounds will get a bit crunchier as development progresses.

Free to Play aspects:
From what is there so far, it looks like cash shop purchases are cosmetic only. If this stays this way, I will gladly drop a few dollars here and there just to get the saltiest taunts and sexiest skins. As of right now there doesn't seem to be a way to earn currency by playing.

Early Access Notes;
For an early access release, this game is remarkably solid already. There's a nice variety in characters, average variety in weapons and a few usable items already. Stages are alright so far, those that exist are pretty distinct from each other. Netcode is okay, though the servers lump everyone together at the moment, as it seems, so expect some teleporting enemies every now and then.

For now, I can thoroughly recommend this game to everyone who likes Smash Brothers or fighting games in general. It is that good. Not just a clone or cash-in on the I want Smash for PC!" audience but an actual possible contender-in-the-making for the genre throne. We'll see how this changes as development progresses

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brawlhalla is a great game, many say it's a copy of Super Smash Bros but it's a totally differnt game. In Brawlhalla you have a set of 2 weapons for each character, you can pick up these weapon holograms(thats what I think they are) around the map and they give you one of your 2 weapons. You can throw these weapons for many reason, damage your opponent(not much), prevent them from recovering, ect.

As of now there are 3 modes, online, custom match, ranked 1v1.

Online - You go into a FFA with 4 people, the one that gets the most points win

Custom Match - In this mode you can do almost anything in the other modes with more. You can have bots, you can also do FFA, BrawlBall, BombsketBall, and Stock Mode. This mode is usually where you just invite friends and play with each other.

Ranked  1v1- Where most of the action takes place, you do 1v1s, of course, and you get ranked on how many games you win and there are 5 divisions. Tin, Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum, and Diamond. You can get into the top 100 hundread and it will show you're on the top 100 in-game.

That's the base of the game but there so much more like characters and their signatures, maps, stratgies, ect.

I recommend this game, just remember, don't get salty :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, real talk review time. My Nope" comment just came out of frustration and a lack of time to acutally create a legitimate review.

Brawlhalla is a very fun game. A very laid back action game that you can have a great time with while playing with your friends. I was given somewhere near 50 or so beta codes to give out
date: I gave all of them away before open beta. I made sure all of my friends and even my enemies had them (but I told the latter to go to ranked). It really is a great party game that has online and local play. Awesome.\n\nNow let's get down to competitve play.There are some key weapons that need to be touched on before I can consider this a true fighting game. Speaking of true
recommended: welcome to the basis of competitive play in this game. True combos. Every weapon in this game has some sort of true combo a.k.a a combo that is guaranteed or inescapable. While that in itself is fine
hoursPlayed: the simplicity of getting these combos makes the game incredibly easy and it makes spam less punishable.\n\nSpeaking of punishes
voteText: holy lord the dodging in this game. Ever since they changed the way that dodges work in this game
helpfulPercent:
hitting attacks seems almost inconsistent. I'm not sure if I am personally not able to adapt or if some weird frame stuff is happening.

Two weapons in this game stand above all others. The rocket lance and the katars.
The rocket lance has great option coverage
votesHelpful: great movement
votesTotal: true combos
votesFunny: you name it. This weapon is just beyond all others and in the hands of a good player

column19: all with there own strengths and weaknesses.\n\nOnce these things are fixed
column20: I think the game will be very well rounded. I do not think this game will approach the levels of other fighting games
column21: but it can at least be balanced.\n\nWhile this is not necessarily justification for people taking my word on the subject

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNetcode could use some work, some characters require balancing, and of course some fundamentals could be improved or changed. Not going to go into any detail beyond that as it's just what you'd expect from a game that's always changing and adapting, in time this game will achieve greatness and it's already come a very long way since alpha. Nothing but improvements have been made with this game aside from some balancing choices (but that's based on opinion of course), overall this game is really fun and extremely competitive. There's no reason not to give it a try as sign ups are free on the website, I would definitely give this game a try. Bottom line it's a good Smash Brother's type of alternative, it's not a completely broken early access game, and the devs seem to be always active and wanting to fix and improve things, everything about it is pretty solid.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From just about 30 min of gameplay, this game has proved itself plenty times. It also has perfectly executed all of the things that are required in a super-smashy game.
- Fluid combat and gameplay
- Wonderful music that goes really well alongside the gameplay
- Decently intelligent AI
- MULTIPLAYER!!!
- And finally, an well balanced pool of characters to choose from

Although I did experience a lot of issues on the multiplayer side with a lot of latency and lag, single player was amazing <3 The character hitbox sometimes seemed weird and it just needs a bit more polish. More content would be nice which I will definitely be looking forward to (char customisation, more maps and chars, etc.) and after all, it is only in early access :3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely amazing game. Did you want the new SSB but you didn't have a wii u? Well Brawlhalla here to save your little nintendoless ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. 11 characters I believe and after 4 and a half hours of play time I still haven't tried them all, and they are all fun with different playstyles and strengths and weaknesses. Multiple weapons each character (legend) has 2 of these weapons they can use, further increasing the diversity of playstyle. Unlike SSB, hit boxes in this game actually make some sense, and it has the unique feature of being able to grab onto the side of the wall. This game also has SKINS. Not only just skins for legends but also weapon skins, death animations (TBR), taunts, probably some more future things you will definently waste your money on (which I have avoided so far). Quality game, get your friends in for an amazing party game, or play online relaxed, or some competitive 1v1 ranked. I don't see this at all as a SBB clone but instead a very good alternative in the form of a pc game.  Once it's released I presume more and better servers will be around and the occassional lag spikes will go away. Tons of money to be wasted, tons of replay value, and tons of fun.
I give it a solid 9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sign up for beta at brawlhalla.com  ~~ its worth it

Amazing game. Plays a lot like Smash Bros but the combat is certainly different.  Awesome art style :)
There are currently 6 types of weapons.  Sword, spear, lance, guns, hammer, and katars.  Each different weapon has a different playstyle and each character has two weapon specalizations. Katar/guns are quite fast , hammer and lance are quite slow, sword and spear are pretty quick but more or less in the middle.
Still needs some time to smooth out some imbalances and reduce server lag.
Developer seems pretty devoted to it thus far!


TL;DR:  Recommend.  Weapons.  Punching.  Throwing.  Explosions.  PvP.  Developer has a pulse.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you liked Super Smash Bros, you should give this game a try. The learning curve is gentle, which is nice... we all can enjoy a casual game every now and then. The game seems more heavily focused on the items rather than creating a specific moveset for every character. Of course, a game this early in development can and will change dramatically. But I do enjoy setting up mines and then using a hammer to knock an enemy straight into one. Also, the bots are pushovers. Online play, while a bit laggy, is surprisingly very entertaining. I'd like a post-game chat feature, though. Anyways, keep up the good work, Blue Mammoth Games! This game has incredible potential and I have a feeling that the developers will create something amazing out of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me first say, I bought this before there were 10+ reviews, going off the description and one or two positive reviews. And by bought, I do in fact mean BOUGHT, as in paid for the standard game.

~{GAMEPLAY}~
The gameplay, like most reviews, is a SM4SH-like game, with some different aspects. There are set weapons, two per character, and fists you must use without a weapon. There are quite a few different weapons but they are all generally just an up close and personal punch-fest. It is very fun thought. The keyboard controls are fine, but the gamepad controls are PERFECT. I never even needed to look or bind the controls when I used a gamepad, so if you have one and pick up this game, USE IT.

~{THE REST}~
I'm too dang lazy to finish this review. My pizza just finished and I'm starving so I'm gonna go eat.

tl;dr buy this game or get it free is up 2 u

reviewText:
Early Access Review

People will tell you this is just a Super Smash Brothers clone for PC, but coming from a person who got it back in 1.0.5, it is actually pretty different and tons of fun. Keep in mind the trailer is outdated and at the time of writing this (August 2015, patch 1.15.1) Brawlhalla is still in closed beta. You can get a free code at www.brawlhalla.com but you'll be missing some sweet costumes.

The menus are very well laid out, the only tweak I would make is that Exit Game is in Options instead of on the main menu and the main menu needs a bit of noise at the bottom.

The cartoony artwork combined with the sounds and the character diversity are amazingly done. All the map layouts are balanced (Exept for Titan's End) and the character choices are great. Bear vs cowgirl, minotaur vs knight, it's amazing the amount of work that Blue Mammoth Games does.

Each character (called Legends) starts out with an unarmed moveset and if you get a weapon pickup, your character will get one of their two assigned weapons each with three signature moves that only they have. Also, each character has their own stats. This means all the characters will be vastly more balanced but still feel different.

Brawlhalla is great as a first fighting game. Each character has 11 unarmed moves and 11 moves per weapon, 6 of which are unique to them. This is much more understandable than the ~20 moves Super smash Bros. has, where no characters share the same two moves.

This is also a great game competitively, don't get me wrong.

The Compettitive and casual communities are great. You can get advice from the best by hanging out in their streams and I think that's amazing. Raidhyn is our main guide maker, so go to his youtube and twitch. We also have our fair share of memes, more f which are created each day, but if you don't care about that, it woln't be waved in your face.

Bottom Line: This is one of my favorite games of all time and it keeps getting better. Tons of fun with friends, and go get it now. Go to Raidhyn's youtube and Twitch to get better, and see the reddit thread for helpful links to help you get started!
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

People say this game is a Smash clone. I say, is that really a bad thing? Who doesn't love a game of Smash Bros?

Try this game. It's got a lot of things going for it.

Pros:
-Amazing lag free online play
-Crisp gameplay mechanics
-Easy to pick up for people new to fighting games
-Tons of depth to sink your teeth into if you're a seasoned fighting game veteran
-Very cool art style (reminded me a lot of Skull Girls)
-Awesome back ground music
-Simple game mechanics (jump, light attack, heavy attack, throw item)
-Big roster that will continue to grow over time
-All stages are fun

Cons:
-In-game currency is useless if you bought all current and future legends with real money. (You can't unlock skins, taunts, or weapon skins with the in-game currency)
-Uh... I can't think of anything else.  I guess a con would be that people compare it to Smash Bros and that makes people think why should I play this if I played Smash?"

Because this game is awesome.  That's why you should play this game."

I'm not even thinking about quiting this game soon. I got this game through entering in for a closed beta key. It was worth the wait. At last I finally recieved a key for the Beta of Brawlhalla and I... REGRET.... NOTHING. I can see me putting 200+ hours in this game soon. Let me explain.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Pros:
Online is amazing
Gameplay is fun
Its kinda like SSB But at the same time nothing like it. It just reminds me of it.
Addicting
Fun to play with friends
Comp is better than CS:Go
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Cons:
Online sometimes lags, althought I only lagged twice from 40+ games
Comp can make you throw your controller or keyboard out the window because of spammers.
Pisols are OP
Hammers are OP
Spears are OP
Thrusters are OP
Swords are OP
Fists are OP
Game is OP
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Moral of the story. This game is amazing, yet at times annoying, not cause of the game, the people. We need a better combo system xD everyone keeps spamming pistols, going behind you and blasting you to pieces. Overall this game gets a 9/10, players get a 5/10. I lost to this guy, I typed gg, he typed this was 2 ez. ;-;

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My relationship with this game is a bittersweet one. On one hand I don't experience any lag and I enjoy the game, on the other I get tons of lag and feel like punching my screen. Bad doesn't even begin to describe how poor the gameplay gets when there is lag, sometimes on your screen you may hit persons with items but then 2 seconds later that's not what happened according to the server and other times you may be standing still and you suddenly fall off the map and there are even times where everyone starts running off the map and dying on your screen. Some minor gripes I also have are how much users with swords and katars can spam attacks and the size of spears' hitboxes being to large.
Don't be discouraged by these minor issues though the game is really fun and has a good community

TL;DR - Game is fun when there isn't lag, virtually unplayable with it. Some stuff should get nerfed.

PS. - When you see all legends as free you only get one of them and not all like I wrongly assumed when I started playing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From what I've played so far this game is an upgrade from Super Smash Bros.

This game is free while Smash for Wii U sells for $60

Although Smash has more characters, the characters in Brawlhalla are all very different.
each character is special in his/her own way.

The combat in Brawlhalla feels very smooth and although similar to other 2D fighting games it has its own twists that makes the game very enjoyable and challenging at the same time.

In brawlhalla you unlock characters by buying them with coins or using the premium currency.
The game is not P2W in any aspect as all characters are balanced.

Conclusion:
This game is only in beta and it is already superior to other AAA fighting games.

The game is free so there is no reason not to try it.

Brawlhalla ‚â• Smash

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played this game for a really long time now, and all I can say is this:
IF YOU ARE A FAN OF SMASH BROS/BRAWLER GAMES, THIS IS THE GAME FOR YOU
PROS:
New legends come out nearly every month.
Almost no bugs in the game.
Servers from all around the world.
Local, online, or ranked play.
Each legend has 6 signature moves, and 2 weapons.
Katars, pistols, swords, spears, bows, hammers, and rocket lances..
And the best part is..
IT'S COMPLETELY FREE TO PLAY
You can buy skins or taunts for real money, but they only benefit how you look in the game.

CONS:
Community is kind of very salty.
Combos are hard to learn, but once you get the hang of them it's fine.

Anyway, I give this game a 8.8/10
(The extra 1.2 left is because I ran out of salt to fill it all)

Get this game, give it a try.

I'm out ~Darkel

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have only three major gripes about this otherwise fantastic game.

The first and most prominent is that there needs to be more variety between the characters, such as differing heights and statures, as well as having completely unique movesets for each as opposed to just different signature moves and weapons (Why the hell can't Teros use his horns while unarmed?! Plus, he's a frickin' minotaur; he should TOWER above the rest!)

Secondly, I'd like to see some way to get unlockable skins by some in-game means rather than purchase. I completely understand why this is so currently and I don't expect it to change while the game is an open beta. Just wishful thinking, I suppose. I could live without it.

And finally, it needs a colorblind mode: simply because I've been corrected by my girlfriend and others way too many times about whether my character was red or brown, blue or purple, green or orange, etc.


Even if none of these were ever added I would still love the living ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of this game. Just to a lesser extent than I would if they were added. It's wonderfully addicting and typically involves lots of skill in ranked matches.

(I didn't include toxic players in my list because that's not exactly something that can be fixed. Much as I would love it to be.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brawlhalla. The game that is so awesome I practiced on it for 3 hours straight so I could beat my friends. The game that 6 of my friends now have, and the other friend who invited me.

Let's get down to buisness:

- It is Free to Play, but not Pay to Win. Every single thing bought from the Mallhalla is cosmetic only.

-Amazing cartoon styled graphics.

-Dev team responds to ideas and actually uses them.

-Gameplay is near-flawless. Multiplayer had major lag, but that was fixed in an update. Now the servers are much more fluid.

Overall just amazing. I give this game a 100. Out of 10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You may think that this a just another ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Smash clone, but it isn't.

BrawlHalla is a fantastic game! It shares a lot of characteristics with the Smash-Bros series but differs enough that it isn't a straight up clone. The weapon system is really cool and each character has unique features, which is great! I have a lot of friends that were very skeptical of this game but they all loved it after playing it.

One of the best things about Brawlhalla is that it's new and still in early access. The developpers are super involved with the community and the game has lots of updates and fixes. There will be tons of new content added to the game in the future so we have lots to look forward to!

-Wizard
P.S. I have many more hours than it says (my computer was not hooked up to ethernet and I was playing offline...).
